Yes.

I support the motion to hold this ordinance, the vote on this ordinance until the later date.
However, I just wanted to make a few comments quickly about the ordinance itself.
The ordinance itself is something that will strip grocery workers of hazard pay three years earlier than was determined by the ordinance that offered hazard pay to grocery workers last year.

Hazard pay ordinance the council passed last year required big grocery workers to pay workers an additional $4.00 an hour in hazard pay for the dangers they undertake doing essential work during the pandemic.
Their work brings them into contact with so many people throughout the day every day.
The hazard pay ordinance lasted three years until the end of the public health emergency.
The public health emergency is not over yet and I think it is absolutely premature to talk about stripping the hazard pay, or stripping is essential workers of their hazard pay.
I do not agree with that.
I don't think it is late enough in August either.
I would like to tell members of the public what my position is.
Holding it is the least thing that should be done . We should at least maintain the hazard pay for the originally determined three years.
If Councilmembers agree with me, we can just vote no on stripping grocery workers of hazard pay altogether and keep the original three here requirement.
Thank you.
Thank you, Councilmember Sawant.
Are there any other comments on the motion to hold Council bill 120119 until August 9th?

We will open the remote public comment period on the introduction referral calendar and work program.
I thank everyone for their ongoing patience as we continue to operate this remote public comment system.
It remains our strong intent to have remote public comment regularly on meeting Agendas.
As a reminder, the city council holds the right to end public comment if our meetings are not being held efficiently and effectively.
I will moderate the public comment period in the following manner today.
Public comment period for today was scheduled to occur for 20 minutes.
A Speaker will have up to two minutes to address the Council.
However, we do have a very large volume of individuals signed up and present to address the Council today.

We have approximately 60, maybe 55 individuals who are witness to provide public comment this afternoon, so in the spirit of wanting to hear from as many folks as we can, I am going to request to have the Council public comment period extended.
If there is no objection, the public comment period will be extended from 20 minutes to a total of 30 minutes.
Hearing no objection, the public comment period is extended for a total of 30 minutes.
I will also need to reduce the amount of time allotted to each Speaker . again, in the spirit of wanting to hear from as many individuals that Preregistered work of the public comment.
Instead of doing two minutes, I will ask the clerk provide each individual with--let's see.
Let's start off with 60 seconds for each Speaker.
Again, I may need to reduce that further in order to maximize the number of folks who took the time to sign up for public comment today.
Let's go ahead and set the clock to 60 seconds.
Thank you, Madam clerk . again, each Speaker is going to have one minute to address the Council.
Again, each Speaker is going to be called upon based on the order in which they registered on the Council's Website.
The Speaker needs to call in using the phone number used for this registration.
Please keep in mind the number that you are calling into is different from the general meeting listen line Call-In information.
Each Speaker will be called on in the order in which they registered on the Council's Website . Each Speaker is asked to begin addressing the Council by reminding us of your name.
You will hear a prompt of you have been on muted . that means it is your turn to press Star six before you begin to speak.

Again, once you hear the prompt of you have been on muted, you need to press Star six in order to Unmute yourself . please begin by stating your name, the item you are addressing, and as a reminder, your items should refer to the items on today's agenda or the work program.

You will hear a Chime at about 10 seconds . that means you have 10 seconds left to wrap up your public comment . If you have not ended your comment at the end of the time provided, your microphone will be muted so I can call on the next Speaker.
Once you have completed your public comment, Disconnect from the line and follow this meeting on the Seattle channel or one of the listening options on the agenda.
The public comment period is now open.
Again, I will call on speakers.
Please press Star six after you hear the prompt of you have been on muted . first three speakers are Howard Gail, Shelby Handler, and Dwight Serrano.
Howard, welcome.
Good afternoon . Howard Gail.
Last year we have seen the repeated failures of every aspect of our police accountability system.
They held a rare once in six years public forum in February to solicit input on how police complaints should be investigated and promptly voted not to do with the community demanded.
We have seen police accountability Handout meaningless discipline in over 99% of the police abuse cases in the last year.

Last year we witness the latest failure of the system as the officer of Inspector General released their first findings on police abuse from a 12 member panel that included 7 people that are part of the system including five SPD officers, four of whom had decades of questionable claims against them and only one member that identified as a Protester.
It is as if the city held a piece circle for domestic violence victims.
This demonstrates the need for full community control over police policy, misconduct, and discipline.
Go to Seattle stop --

My name is Shelby Handler and I am a Jewish resident calling from district to, calling in strong support of CB 12142, calling on city Council to support legislation to prohibit SPD from training with all countries that are committing grave, ongoing human rights abuses.
Our city needs to stop spending resources on supporting violations of international law and instead we should put our investments in black led solutions for safety.
As a Jewish resident, I really want to say this loud and clear.
When we resist white supremacy we are resisting anti-Semitism.

Don't let anyone tell you otherwise . I know I feel deep in my body when we invest in communities that are most impacted by these systems it makes all of us more safe, including Jewish folks of all races . We need to stop investing in racist and Militarized policing . Thank you so much.
Thank you.

Council bill 120126, relating to Seattle parks and recreation authorizing an exchange of city-owned property at Walt Hundley Playfield for property owned by Seattle school district no.
1 adjacent to West Seattle elementary school.

Thank you, Council president and thank you to allow this item to advance to full council so Seattle parks and public schools can meet their deadline.

Colleagues, as I shared with you in an Email on Friday, July 23rd, this executive proposed legislation will authorize an exchange of city-owned property at Walt Hundley Playfield adjacent to West Seattle elementary school . We have done these common property swaps between parks and other city departments such as the zoo and Aquarium and now we are doing another one for Seattle public schools . Seattle public schools and parks and Rec began the process of formally transferring these two pieces of property in the 1980s but did not complete the legal process required for transferring the properties including the execution of quick claim deeds . The property trade involves two pieces of land of equal value and size.
This will give Seattle parks and Rec full control and Seattle public schools full control and order to develop its property at the elementary school.
It ensures a portion of the property be transferred to Seattle public schools were made available for public outdoor recreation through the execution of a local agreement between the two agencies.
Madam President, I recommend the Council pass this bill.
Thank you.
Thank you, Councilmember Juarez . Councilmember Herbold, do you have your hand raised?
I want to thank Councilmember Juarez for bringing this forward . I want to add a little bit of more detail about the Interlocal agreement.

The agreement specifies that the District will not develop or fenced off the public recreation portion but will have the ability to install a gate in the existing fence that will allow students to access and recreate . Neither agency will be required to compensate the other for the exchange . The legislation does not in any way change the current use of the affected use of property.
They will continue to be used as they are now but with appropriately upheld by the correct agency user.

Agenda item 2, court file 314479. designation of facial recognition technology as surveillance technology pursuant to Seattle surveillance ordinance, Seattle municipal code 14.18.020.
Thank you so much.
I moved to approve CF 314479.
Is there a second?
Second.
It has been moved and Seconded to approve CF 314479 . I will hand it over to Councilmember Herbold who is a cosponsor of this item to address the item.
Thank you again so much . I really appreciate the ability to work with Councilmember Pedersen on this bill.
He is the chair of the committee that has oversight of the surveillance technology related action.

Since this is a clerk file to the surveillance ordinance, I really appreciate his leadership in helping me work through some of the issues related to our recent office of professional accountability investigation where the director concluded that an officer's use of facial recognition technology was not in violation of the city surveillance ordinance.

We received analysis from central staff . The analysis shows that the facial recognition technology is currently within the jurisdiction and Purview of the surveillance ordinance, meaning the use of the technology is currently Pivoted unless reviewed and approved as described in the graphic, or as described in the ordinance itself . In order to eliminate any confusion in the future, whether facial recognition technology is covered by the surveillance ordinance, council central staff recommended we use the clerk file as the mechanism for the particular clarification.
We also sort of heard a differing opinions from chief Diaz in the Seattle police Department back in November of 2020 when this issue was first brought to public awareness.
Chief Diaz wrote that SPD does not use a clear view ai and he went on to say as chief I am committed to upholding the tenant of the surveillance ordinance and civil liberties of our residents.

It is at odd with those two central priorities . further on my request again last year, the chief sent out a Departmentwide communication reminding everyone in the Seattle police Department about the policy.
It made clear that one cannot use personal technology as a means to bypass city policies.
It included the review of SPD and the actual content of the policy.
Recently the chief publicly indicated it is a gray area, saying it is not chief Diaz's position to cover the use of the facial recognition software.

Again, the clerk file before the Council will ensure that in the future the surveillance ordinance is very clear that it does include the use of facial recognition technology and will be subject to the review process outlined in the ordinance.
Thank you.
Thank you so much, Councilmember Herbold . any additional comments on the clerk file?
Councilmember Pedersen, please.

Thank you, Council President . colleagues, as I mentioned this morning our transportation and utilities committee amended and unanimously recommended CB 120115 . This bill will enable our Seattle Department of transportation to better manage on Street parking availability in the uptown neighborhood by increasing parking rates as needed during large events at Seattle center . large events are likely to include sports at the climate pledge arena formerly known as key arena.
We unanimously adopted the bill on the seventh but we had the legislation arrived at today's council meeting, a full three Council meetings later in case the public wanted more time to comment.

Thank you so much, Councilmember Pedersen . any additional comments on the bill?
Councilmember Lewis.

Thank you so much, Madame President . As I am not a member of the transportation Committee, today has been my first opportunity to engage in the Council process on this bill . I want to thank Councilmember Pedersen for providing space to meet and discuss potential concerns.

I got the run up on his process and Committee and I do appreciate that that process was inclusive of my positions as a Councilmember presenting uptown . I do feel like I should make a statement on the legislation now that it is facing final passage and I have the first opportunity to weigh in with an official vote on it.

I do support the legislation and I think it is important we have a strategy around the finite parking supply in the uptown neighborhood and how the coming significantly large events at the climate pledge arena will affect that parking supply . I do want to put on the record for folks watching and this will probably be redundant to the discourse in the transportation committee but for the first hour or first two hours of parking, the rate will be assessed at $3.00 an hour.
For the second period it will be assessed at $8.00 an hour with the director discretion to increase to $12.00 an hour.

For a four hour period, folks that pay up to $24.00 were up to $30.00 if the full discretion afforded to the director is prevented . I think it is important to acknowledge that the uptown neighborhood has considerable additional demands as a neighborhood with a number of small businesses with additional arts and entertainment facilities in the region, all of which will be competing for limited parking supply . I do want to go on the record and say I think it is important that when we are planning moving several thousand people into a discrete area, we provide incentives to take advantage of the multitude of direct bus routes to go to the campus from all over the city of Seattle that we take advantage of the souped-up Monorail transfer that is going to be available to visitors on game days to transfer from the lightning rail at Westlake to the Monorail in order to get to the center campus . We can't forget the upcoming Thomas Street improvements that this Council has supported for a number of years to increase bike and pedestrian office to facilitate potential parking and provide a good pedestrian promenade to the Seattle center campus.
We are anticipating moving significant numbers of people to the Seattle center.
There are a considerable number of alternatives to driving.

If folks are driving, we need to make sure we are doing our due diligence to make sure the parking is being rationed in a way that can coexist with some of the other demands that uptown neighborhood faces for street parking and make sure we are Incentivizing other methods to get to the center campus without relying on single occupancy vehicles.
With that, I will be voting for this . considering it is limited to situations when there are large events, this is not new.
$24 a day for parking in the uptown neighborhood is a reasonable course of action by the Department.
Thank you so much, Councilmember Lewis.
Any additional comments on the bill?
All right.

The bill passes . will the clerk please affix my signature on my behalf?
